content: boom by playing with fibre boom is a formula for a simple asymmetrical scarf intended for use with any thickness of yarn with appropriate needles the pattern includes two examples of different sizes abbreviations k knit k2tog knit two stitches together 1 stitch decreased kfb knit into front and back of same stitch 1 stitch increased st stitch additional materials darning needle for weaving in ends optional stitch marker to mark right side of fabric note to adjust size or for different yarn quantities & thicknesses cast on using needles appropriate for your yarn continue to knit until you are almost out of yarn leaving just enough to bind off bind off block & weave in ends email playingwithfibre@gmail com pattern & photos eimear earley 2016 instagram @playswithfibre updated 2020 twitter @pwfibre boom page 1 of 3 version 1 size wingspan 180 cm / 70 depth 30 cm /11 8 yarn 300 metres / 330 yards aran weight yarn this sample uses handspun yarn made using 150g of wingham wool work s merino tops in giggleswick gauge 14 sts & 34 row per 10 cm / 4 in garter stitch needles 6mm or size needed to achieve gauge instructions cast on 5 sts row 1 k1 kfb k to last 2 sts k2tog row 2 k to last 2 sts kfb k1 repeat row 1 and 2 until there are 120 sts bind off block gently by soaking in warm water pressing out excess water between rolled up towels and smooth knitting over a flat surface to dry weave in ends version 2 size wingspan 98 cm / 38 5 depth 17 cm / 6 5 yarn 88 m / 96 yards of chunky weight yarn this sample uses handspun yarn made using 114 g of hand dyed tops gauge 12 st & 26 row over 10cm / 4 in garter stitch needles 7mm or size needed to achieve gauge instructions cast on 5 sts row 1 k1 kfb k to last 2 sts k2tog row 2 k to last 2 sts kfb k1 repeat row 1 and 2 until there are 54 sts block gently by soaking in warm water pressing out excess water between rolled up towels and smooth knitting over a flat surface to dry weave in ends boom page 2 of 3 notes for spinning your own yarn this pattern was originally conceived as a showcase for handspun yarns to use as much of the yarn as possible and to show colour arrangement within the fibre the notes below describe the fibre arrangement as shown in sample 1 handspun gradient sample 1 used 150g of wingham wool works merino tops in the giggleswick colour way this is a blended fibre with multiple colours i separated the colours into 4 groups as follows colour a light green colour b dark green colour c blue colour d pink i separated the fibre colours a b and c into bundles of approximately 1/3
